questiontext.text: A multifunctional substrate contains an aldehyde, a ketone, and a free alcohol. The target is to reduce only the aldehyde to a primary alcohol, keep the ketone unchanged, and finally convert the original free alcohol into a tosylate, without ever exposing the aldehyde to strong base. Which strategy is most consistent with orthogonality and chemoselectivity?

generalfeedback.text: A silyl ether protection masks the alcohol without requiring strongly basic conditions, and it is orthogonal to many reduction conditions; after chemoselective aldehyde reduction (using mild/controlled hydride conditions), deprotection can regenerate the alcohol for tosylation. Protecting the aldehyde as an acetal typically requires acid and adds unnecessary steps, while LiAlH4 risks reducing the ketone and may react with sulfonates. Protecting the ketone as a ketal still leaves the aldehyde exposed and does not prevent competing reduction or side reactions as effectively as a designed chemoselective sequence. Tosylating first can introduce competing reactivity and does not address chemoselectivity during reduction.

answer.text: Protect the aldehyde as an acetal, tosylate the alcohol, then reduce with LiAlH4, then deprotect
Protect the ketone as a ketal, reduce with NaBH4, then tosylate the alcohol, then deprotect
Protect the free alcohol as a silyl ether, reduce aldehyde selectively at low temperature, then deprotect and tosylate
Tosylate the free alcohol first, then reduce aldehyde with LiAlH4, then selectively hydrolyze any over-reduction products

questiontext.text: In a diastereoselective addition to an α-alkoxy aldehyde, two sets of conditions are compared: (i) a non-coordinating nucleophile/conditions and (ii) a Lewis-acid-promoted condition that enables chelation. The major product switches between the two conditions. What is the best mechanistic rationale?

generalfeedback.text: α-Alkoxy (or α-hydroxy) carbonyls can coordinate to Lewis acids/metal cations, forming chelated transition states that enforce a different substrate conformation and hence different facial approach than the non-chelated Felkin–Anh-type arrangement. Racemization is not the primary expectation for simple α-alkoxy aldehydes under typical chelation conditions. Thermodynamic interconversion of diastereomeric alcohol products is generally not fast without specific epimerization pathways. SN1-like ionization at the α-carbon is not the key process in nucleophilic addition to carbonyls.

answer.text: The aldehyde racemizes under Lewis acid, reversing configuration and hence product identity
The reaction changes from kinetic control to thermodynamic control, interconverting diastereomers
The dominant transition state changes from Felkin–Anh (non-chelation) to chelation-controlled, changing facial selectivity
The nucleophile changes from hard to soft, forcing SN1-like ionization at the α-carbon

questiontext.text: A synthetic plan aims to obtain an enantioenriched product from a racemate with theoretical yield greater than 50% of a single enantiomer. Which approach most directly enables that goal, assuming an appropriate racemization pathway exists?

generalfeedback.text: Simple kinetic resolution is intrinsically capped at 50% maximum yield of the desired enantiomer because the other enantiomer remains unreacted. Dynamic kinetic resolution (DKR) couples selective conversion of one enantiomer with racemization of the remaining enantiomer, allowing continued conversion and thus yields beyond 50% while maintaining high enantioenrichment. Classical resolution separates enantiomers but does not inherently exceed 50% without recycling/racemization steps; desymmetrization applies to prochiral/meso substrates, not a racemate.

answer.text: Classical resolution via diastereomeric salt formation
Simple kinetic resolution using a lipase
Dynamic kinetic resolution combining kinetic resolution with in situ racemization
Desymmetrization of a meso precursor

questiontext.text: In double stereodifferentiation, a chiral substrate is reacted with a chiral reagent/catalyst. Experimentally, one pairing gives high diastereoselectivity, while the opposite enantiomer of the reagent gives much lower selectivity. Which interpretation is most appropriate?

generalfeedback.text: In matched cases, stereochemical preferences of substrate control and reagent/catalyst control align, giving enhanced diastereoselectivity or enantioselectivity. In mismatched cases, the controls oppose, reducing selectivity and sometimes changing the dominant pathway. Enantiomeric reagents do not guarantee identical selectivity ratios with a chiral substrate, because the overall system is not related by simple mirror symmetry. Temperature can affect selectivity but does not remove the fundamental matched/mismatched relationship.

answer.text: The first case is matched, where substrate and reagent controls reinforce; the second is mismatched, where controls oppose
The first case is mismatched, because higher selectivity implies greater competition between controls
Both cases must have identical selectivity because enantiomeric reagents always give mirror-image products in equal ratios
The outcome depends only on temperature, not on reagent chirality, for double stereodifferentiation systems

questiontext.text: A synthesis requires formation of a chiral product from an achiral starting material, and the route must minimize stoichiometric chiral waste while still providing high enantioselectivity. Which method best aligns with that constraint?

generalfeedback.text: Organocatalysis uses a small chiral organic molecule catalytically to induce asymmetry, minimizing stoichiometric consumption of chiral material while targeting high enantioselectivity. Chiral auxiliaries are typically used in stoichiometric amounts (even if recoverable), generating additional steps and mass of auxiliary-bearing intermediates. Classical resolution and diastereomeric salt formation involve separation and often discard or require recycling of the undesired enantiomer, and they do not inherently provide catalytic asymmetric induction from achiral starting materials. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/bbb354c7-10b6-4c64-93aa-f65f58d9fb78/organic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/eecdaa56-93b9-4e87-bc04-9974af604151/inorganic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/d56907a9-060e-4d86-bddd-81839e191ded/organic_unit_08.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/851d31c2-99cf-4f1d-964a-940ec8b03542/inorganic_unit_05.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/cc5a144e-082d-4ed0-9e8b-29621c7ee75d/organic_unit_01.txt)

answer.text: Chiral auxiliary approach, because it guarantees catalytic turnover of the chiral source
Organocatalysis, because the chiral source is catalytic rather than stoichiometric
Classical resolution, because it converts all material into a single enantiomer directly
Diastereomeric salt formation using a resolving agent, because it is always atom-economical

questiontext.text: Which statement best defines chemoselectivity in organic synthesis?

generalfeedback.text: Chemoselectivity refers to a reagent reacting with one functional group selectively when multiple functional groups are present in a molecule. This contrasts with enantioselectivity (one enantiomer favored) and regioselectivity (site preference within similar sites). Selecting reagents/conditions that differentiate functional groups exemplifies chemoselectivity. Options describing enantioselectivity or regioselectivity do not define this principle.

answer.text: Preference for formation of one enantiomer over the other
Preference for reaction at one functional group in the presence of others
Preference for addition to one face of a planar electrophile
Preference for substitution at the least hindered site within the same group

questiontext.text: In electrophilic aromatic substitution, an electron-donating substituent such as –OCH3 typically directs incoming electrophiles to:

generalfeedback.text: Electron-donating groups activate the ring and stabilize sigma complexes at ortho and para positions via resonance, increasing substitution there. Exclusive para or ortho selection is not guaranteed at the basic level; both are favored depending on sterics and conditions. Meta-directing behavior is characteristic of strong electron-withdrawing groups, not –OCH3.

answer.text: Meta position due to deactivation
Ortho/para positions due to activation
Only para position due to steric hindrance
Only ortho position due to resonance donation

questiontext.text: Which choice describes enantioselectivity most accurately?

generalfeedback.text: Enantioselectivity refers to the preferential formation of one enantiomer when a prochiral substrate reacts in a chiral environment (catalyst, auxiliary, enzyme). Diastereoselectivity pertains to preference among diastereomers when stereocenters influence outcomes. Kinetic vs thermodynamic control and aldehyde vs ketone reactivity are unrelated to enantioselectivity definitions.

answer.text: Formation of one diastereomer preferentially in presence of an existing stereocenter
Formation of one enantiomer preferentially from a prochiral substrate
Formation of the kinetic product over the thermodynamic product
Preferential reaction of aldehyde over ketone within the same molecule

questiontext.text: A primary purpose of installing a protecting group during a multistep synthesis is to:

generalfeedback.text: Protecting groups are temporary masks that prevent undesired reactions on sensitive functional groups, enabling selective transformations elsewhere. They must be removable under orthogonal conditions. They do not permanently deactivate or necessarily improve leaving group ability as a goal, and increased molecular weight is incidental, not the purpose.

answer.text: Increase molecular weight for easier purification
Permanently deactivate all reactive sites
Temporarily mask a functional group incompatible with planned steps
Enhance the leaving group ability of the protected site permanently

questiontext.text: Which alcohol protecting group is commonly chosen for acid-sensitive sequences due to base- or fluoride-labile deprotection?

generalfeedback.text: Trialkylsilyl ethers like TBS are stable to many acids and can be removed with fluoride (e.g., TBAF) or base, fitting orthogonal strategies where acid is used elsewhere. Benzyl ethers are typically removed by hydrogenolysis; trityl groups are acid-labile; acetals are acid-labile carbonyl protections, not primarily alcohol protections for acid-sensitive sequences.

answer.text: Benzyl ether
Silyl ether (e.g., TBS)
Trityl ether (Tr)
Acetal from a diol

questiontext.text: Which statement best describes resolution of enantiomers by diastereomeric salt formation?

generalfeedback.text: Chemical resolution often forms diastereomeric salts by reacting a racemic acid or base with a single enantiomer of a resolving agent; the salts have different solubilities/melting points, enabling separation and subsequent recovery. It does not inherently convert both to a single enantiomer without separation, and it creates diastereomers, not enantiomeric salts of identical properties.

answer.text: Converts a racemate directly into a single enantiomer without separation
Produces diastereomeric salts with different physical properties for separation
Requires a chiral catalyst to convert both enantiomers to the same product
Relies on forming enantiomeric salts with identical solubilities

questiontext.text: Desymmetrization is most directly defined as:

generalfeedback.text: Desymmetrization transforms a prochiral or meso compound such that symmetry is broken, creating a chiral center or axis, often using selective reagents or enzymes. Resolution is the separation of racemates via diastereomeric derivatives; converting to meso is the opposite of introducing chirality.

answer.text: Separation of racemates into single enantiomers
Converting a racemic mixture into a meso compound
Selectively transforming a prochiral or meso substrate to generate chirality
Converting enantiomers to diastereomers for separation

questiontext.text: The Evans oxazolidinone is primarily used in synthesis as:

generalfeedback.text: Evans oxazolidinone functions as a temporary chiral auxiliary attached to carboxylic acid derivatives to direct diastereoselective transformations (e.g., aldol), and is later removed and recovered. It is not a catalyst, not permanent, and is not a hydrogen-bond donor organocatalyst.

answer.text: A permanent chiral auxiliary embedded in the final product
A temporary chiral auxiliary to control diastereoselectivity in reactions like aldol
A chiral phase-transfer catalyst for SN2 substitutions
A hydrogen-bond donor organocatalyst for Diels–Alder reactions

questiontext.text: Proline in asymmetric organocatalysis typically operates via which activation mode?

generalfeedback.text: Proline and related secondary amines form enamines (nucleophile activation) or iminium ions (electrophile activation), enabling enantioselective aldol and Michael additions through chiral enamine/iminium pathways. Organocatalysis here does not involve metal backbonding, radical pathways, or strong acid activation of alkenes.

answer.text: Iminium/enamine activation enabling enantioselective aldol and Michael reactions
Metal–ligand backbonding to lower LUMO of carbonyls
Generation of free radicals via single-electron transfer
Strong Brønsted acid activation of alkenes

questiontext.text: Which statement best captures the concept of double stereodifferentiation?

generalfeedback.text: Double stereodifferentiation arises when both substrate and reagent/catalyst possess stereochemical information; matched cases reinforce selectivity, while mismatched cases reduce or invert it. Exclusive dependence on substrate or reagent alone does not describe the phenomenon, and independence from both is incorrect. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/bbb354c7-10b6-4c64-93aa-f65f58d9fb78/organic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/eecdaa56-93b9-4e87-bc04-9974af604151/inorganic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/f41187d8-4c1f-42a8-b69c-1b08ca48bd7f/organic_unit_04.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/710f5898-842c-4d82-ad4a-29c3aa7a6003/organic_unit_06.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/1f657058-509e-4057-ad33-3e519f1d9672/inorganic_unit_01.txt)

answer.text: Only substrate control dictates stereochemical outcome
Only reagent/catalyst control dictates stereochemical outcome
Substrate and reagent/catalyst chirality act together, leading to matched or mismatched cases
Stereochemical outcomes are independent of both substrate and reagent chirality

questiontext.text: A molecule bears an aldehyde and an ester. Which single reagent-condition set most directly gives the primary alcohol from the aldehyde with minimal ester reduction at low temperature?

generalfeedback.text: At −78 °C, DIBAL-H reduces aldehydes rapidly, while esters are reduced more slowly and often stop at the aldehyde after controlled quench; this enables chemoselective reduction of the aldehyde in the presence of an ester. LiAlH4 and LiBH4 are too reactive and reduce esters; NaBH4 is mild but may still reduce aldehydes while leaving esters mostly untouched, not delivering the desired selectivity profile as reliably as low-temperature DIBAL control.

answer.text: LiAlH4, THF, 0–25 °C
NaBH4, MeOH, 0–25 °C
DIBAL-H, toluene, −78 °C, then MeOH quench
LiBH4, THF, reflux

questiontext.text: In a substrate containing both an aldehyde and a ketone, which condition favors chemoselective nucleophilic addition at the aldehyde?

generalfeedback.text: Aldehydes are more electrophilic and less sterically hindered than ketones, so a strong, fast nucleophile at low temperature (e.g., RLi) will preferentially add to the aldehyde under kinetic control. Softer cuprates may favor conjugate additions and be less reactive to simple carbonyls; hindered Grignards at reflux can cause side reactions; “bulky, less basic hydride” is vague and may not ensure selectivity in C–C bond formation.

answer.text: Use of a hindered Grignard reagent at reflux
Use of a softer cuprate at −78 °C
Use of a bulky, less basic hydride at −78 °C
Use of a strong organolithium at −78 °C

questiontext.text: For EAS on a ring bearing both –OCH3 and –NO2, the predominant regioisomer with Br2/FeBr3 is expected at:

generalfeedback.text: –OCH3 is a strong ortho/para director and activates the ring, while –NO2 is a strong meta director but deactivating; the activated sites ortho/para to –OCH3 are favored for electrophilic substitution, typically overriding the deactivated positions influenced by –NO2. Thus bromination occurs mainly ortho/para to –OCH3.

answer.text: Meta to –OCH3 due to deactivation by –NO2
Ortho/para to –OCH3 because it is strongly activating and outcompetes –NO2
Meta to –NO2 because –NO2 is a meta director and dominates
Ortho to –NO2 due to its strong –I effect

questiontext.text: Addition of a nucleophile to an α-chiral aldehyde lacking coordinating heteroatoms usually follows:

generalfeedback.text: Absent coordinating substituents, classical Cram steric approach control often predicts major diastereomer via attack from the less hindered face at the carbonyl. Chelation control becomes important with α-alkoxy/amine substituents under Lewis acidic conditions; Felkin–Anh refines Cram by including electronic effects with electronegative α-substituents.

answer.text: Chelation-controlled model with synclinal approach
Cram’s steric approach model favoring attack from the least hindered face
Prelog’s rule mandating opposite facial selectivity to Cram
Felkin–Anh model dominated exclusively by electronic effects with no steric input

questiontext.text: A meso-1,2-diol undergoes selective monoacylation by a lipase to give a single optically active monoester. This process exemplifies:

generalfeedback.text: Selective transformation of one enantiotopic OH in a meso diol breaks symmetry to give a chiral product, i.e., desymmetrization. Classical salt resolution addresses racemates; simple kinetic resolution caps at 50% conversion to isolate one enantiomer; DKR needs in situ racemization of the unreacted enantiomer, which is not a meso case.

answer.text: Classical resolution via diastereomeric salt formation
Kinetic resolution limited to 50% theoretical maximum
Desymmetrization generating chirality from a meso substrate
Dynamic kinetic resolution requiring racemization catalyst

questiontext.text: Choosing between Boc and Cbz for protecting a primary amine in a sequence that uses strong acid but prohibits hydrogenation, the better choice is:

generalfeedback.text: Boc is acid-labile and typically removed by TFA; it avoids hydrogenation. Cbz is removed by hydrogenolysis, which is prohibited by the sequence; it is not generally base-labile nor acid-labile like tert-butyl esters.

answer.text: Boc, because it is removed by TFA and avoids hydrogenolysis
Cbz, because it is removed under basic conditions
Boc, because it requires hydrogenolysis for removal
Cbz, because it is acid-labile like tert-butyl esters

questiontext.text: A racemic secondary alcohol is subjected to lipase-catalyzed acetate formation, giving 40% conversion and 96% ee in the acetate. The selectivity factor s is closest to:

generalfeedback.text: For kinetic resolution, s = ln[(1−c)(1−ee_s)]/ln[(1−c)(1+ee_s)] or using product ee and conversion relations; at c = 0.40 and product ee_p = 0.96, the calculated s is approximately in the 10–12 range; 12 is the closest of the options. Lower values underestimate the high enantiodiscrimination implied by 96% ee at only 40% conversion.

questiontext.text: In an Evans auxiliary-controlled aldol using a Z-boron enolate, the dominant diastereomer arises from a Zimmerman–Traxler chair in which:

generalfeedback.text: Under boron-mediated aldol conditions with Z-boron enolates, the chair-like Zimmerman–Traxler transition state typically delivers syn aldol products; the Evans auxiliary enforces facial selectivity, enhancing diastereocontrol. E enolates generally favor anti products in this model.

answer.text: Both large groups occupy axial positions, giving anti product
The chiral auxiliary biases approach to give syn aldol from Z enolate
The enolate geometry is irrelevant to syn/anti outcome
E enolates give syn aldol preferentially under boron mediation

questiontext.text: In a proline-catalyzed asymmetric aldol between acetone and p-nitrobenzaldehyde, the origin of enantioselectivity is best attributed to:

generalfeedback.text: Proline forms a chiral enamine with the ketone donor; this enamine adds to the aldehyde (often H-bond activated), and the chiral environment dictates enantiofacial approach, giving enantioenriched aldol products. Iminium activation can be involved with α,β-unsaturated acceptors, but the core mode here is enamine catalysis.

answer.text: Iminium activation of the aldehyde by protonation alone
Enamine formation from acetone and chiral enamine addition to the aldehyde
Metal–ligand backbonding lowering the aldehyde LUMO
Single-electron transfer to generate radical ions

questiontext.text: For competing 1,2- vs. 1,4-addition of MeLi and Me2CuLi to cyclohexenone at −78 °C, the expected major products are:

generalfeedback.text: Hard, highly basic nucleophiles like MeLi favor direct 1,2-addition to the carbonyl, whereas softer cuprates like Me2CuLi favor conjugate (1,4) addition to enones at low temperature, illustrating reagent-controlled regioselectivity. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/bbb354c7-10b6-4c64-93aa-f65f58d9fb78/organic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/d56907a9-060e-4d86-bddd-81839e191ded/organic_unit_08.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/710f5898-842c-4d82-ad4a-29c3aa7a6003/organic_unit_06.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/eecdaa56-93b9-4e87-bc04-9974af604151/inorganic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/0d13af76-414f-4c3b-8d8c-2f6b625d3637/organic_unit_05.txt)

answer.text: MeLi: 1,4-addition; Me2CuLi: 1,2-addition
MeLi: 1,2-addition; Me2CuLi: 1,4-addition
Both give predominantly 1,2-addition under kinetic control
Both give predominantly 1,4-addition due to conjugation
